key_points: On May 7, Russian cybergang DarkSide attacked Colonial Pipeline, causing temporary gas shortages in the US and demanding a $5 million ransom.
US President Joe Biden vowed to disrupt DarkSide's operations after the attack.
DarkSide announced on May 14 that they were shutting down due to pressure from the US, after their servers were knocked offline and bitcoin stolen.
The FBI recovered $2.3 million from the Colonial Pipeline ransom on June 7.
DarkSide appears to have rebranded as "Black Matter" and seeks partners to attack major companies in the US, UK, Canada, or Australia.
Cybersecurity experts believe Black Matter is a reincarnation of DarkSide, following a pattern of hacking groups relaunching under new names.
Some suspect US law enforcement's claimed victory over DarkSide may have been exaggerated.
The US struggles to stop ransomware alone, as criminal groups can easily disband and reconstitute.
A lasting solution requires host countries, like Russia, to crack down on hackers within their jurisdictions.
US and European allies are pressuring resistant governments to act against cybercrime; Biden has warned of the risks of a 'real shooting war' over ransomware attacks.
